docs.lead_paragraph: It might seem like a lot of cash for one super-sized clunker, a good-money-after-bad attempt to jump-start a broken giant of Detroit.
docs.abstract: As the Obama administration contemplates a third rescue of GMAC, the onetime finance arm of General Motors, federal officials, automotive executives and analysts all say the company is - just like the biggest Wall Street firms - too big to fail.

docs.lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, polls have shown solid support for a government-run insurance option, seeming to breathe new life into its viability as a provision of health care legislation. In fact, advocates of the so-called public option -- whether left-leaning groups, pundits or many Democratic lawmakers -- have seized on each new number and trumpeted it across the 24/7 news spectrum. But while those polls may have bolstered Senator Harry Reid's decision this week to include the public option in the merged Senate bill, a closer examination shows once again that public opinion on this issue shifts and shimmies depending on how the question is phrased and what is stripped away from -- or added to -- a compound sentence.
docs.abstract: Polls show solid support for government-run health insurance option, but on close examination issue shifts depending on how question is phrased; chart; graph (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Who needs a motion to proceed? Democratic Congressional leaders have yet to unveil a complete draft of the health care legislation, or formally take up the bill in either chamber. But in a sense, the floor debate is already under way, in extensive floor speeches that Democrats and Republicans alike have started giving.
docs.abstract: Democratic Congressional leaders have yet to unveil complete health-care bill, but debate continues at fever pitch in both chambers (M)
